bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 5, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes his voyage to Cuba. He also comments on the upcoming presidential election in the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 5, 1900
div1.opener:
Monday afternoon
Novr 5th.
Pleasure
no. 1.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
When we
pulled out from our dock in
New York, a strong nor'wester
was already blowing at a
good rate- The sea soon
became rough and topsy tur-
vy, and then I knew that I
was in for a real good time!
I managed to eat a little bit
of my dinner, at 5 o'clock and
quickly thereafter tumbled into
my berth, where needless to
state I have been ever since
one could hardly sleep at all
Saturday night, the boat rolled
from side to side so dreadfully.
It was as much as one
could do to keep from tumb-
ling out. This afternoon she
still rolls, but not enough to
give any trouble- I haven't
been sick all the time by
any means, but have had no
appitite- Have managed to
eat some fruit and now and
then a cup of tea. But I
don't relish any thing- The
Captain, a fat jolly gentleman,
has been in to see me
twice and offered to do any
thing in his power- I've told
him that I thought the best
thing to do was to keep in
my berth and sleep as much
as possible- I have only
“fed the fishes” twice-
I am lying flat of my back
as I write with my paper
propped up against my knees.
It is rather uncomfortable and
I am afraid that my wri-
ting isn't very plain. Be-
sides its just a wee-bit
tiresome- I have thought
a great deal about my
two precious girls and how
sweet they were to Papa
while he was in Washington.
And how sweet they were to
each other too- Papa's big girl
helping his little girl with
her lessons so kindly! Nothing
makes him so happy as to
see his children getting along
sweetly together! Did the
candy arrive from New York
I couldn't go away, although
it was so sloppy and wet, with
out strolling down to 26th St.
and getting something for my pre-
cious girls.

Pleasure no. 2.- Pleasure no. 1. was
rather short, wasn't it, lovie, dear?
I simply had to give up the attempt
yesterday, (this is Tuesday afternoon)
the position in which I was
trying to write was so very
irk some- Last night, I slept
pretty well and when I awoke, was
delighted to see the Florida
Coast once more and to find that
the Seas were quieter and the
boat pitching less- After
2) After one or two attempts,
I got up and bathed my face and
then lay down & waited for my
breakfast of “minched chicken”
“on Toast” and a cup of tea-
To my surprise, I enjoyed them
very much and even ordered
a plate of cakes, which I ate
with relish- After finishing
my toilet, I went to the Barber
shop & got rid of a 3 days growth
of beard and then felt better.
My! but it is hot! we chance
to be travelling with the breeze
& hence get none of it- I got on
deck at 10 a.m. for the first time
since we left N.Y. Enjoyed
my lunch at 1 o'clock very
much and am now taking in
the quiet beauty of the Florida
Coast, while the busy ballot=
tossers in the U.S. are, I hope,
burying that big-mouth Bryan
with a bank of paper! We
will expect to hear something
tomorrow morning when we reach
Havana- My cold clings to me
yet; that is I sneeze occasion-
ally & my head feels a little stuffy,
but it don't bother me much-
I am afraid that end seat
of Miss Mason's table isn't
conducive to good health -
you & fat love had better
avoid it, and let somebody
else sit there who is more
resistant to temperature
changes- It quite did me up-
9.30 P.M. While I had stopped writing
for a moment, a nice looking
gentleman drew his chair up a-
long side of mine and began to
remark on the beauty of the scene.
He is a german, who lives at
Vedado and speaks spanish fluently
We chatted till dinner time, and
after dinner till now, I have been
revelling in the beautiful moon-
light- Such a perfect night and
so balmy and delicious the air
as we approach the Cuban Coast-
we can't be more than 50 miles
away from Cuba now, & when we
awake at 6 a.m., the Mexico
will be tugging at her anchor
in Havana Harbor- I enjoyed
my dinner, but will enjoy my meals
more when I get ashore. I
will leave the balance of this page
for a few words after we arrive-
Good-night, you sweet hearts and
may your dreams be bright and happy
Wednesday 6 a.m. Here we
are in Havana Harbor
& almost ready to land.
The morning is bright and
beautiful and I am feeling
quite jolly to think that
the boat is, at last, at
anchor & quiet.

Have just reached the
Post Office in Dr Agra-
monte's carriage- Love
& kisses for my sweet,
sweet girls-
